segments.text: Sir, this is in regards to the training you received prior to going to Vietnam or even in Vietnam on the Vietnamese culture or language.
Did you receive any training in that area?
During the three weeks at Camp Pendleton, we received training on the Vietnamese culture.
We received a few words or instruction on a few words of Vietnamese, like halt.

do you surrender things of that nature but there was no extensive training language training at all and it was not necessary because the type of contact that an infantry organization has you don't need the language training i don't think it would be cost effective anyway
except for those people that are dealing with Vietnamese on a daily basis and have to be conversable.
In other words, you can be assigned to a built-up area, or to a town like Da Nang, and still not have to speak Vietnamese.
I'm sure there are Vietnamese citizens around, and it would be convenient if you could, but a lot of people have the type of jobs where they do come in daily contact.
We were confident that their job didn't mean that they had to talk to Vietnamese.
You're in a military compound, you're working with other Marines or other Americans, and you can get your job done without the language.
When I was there, there was always a curfew at night.
Of course, Marines worked in the daytime, so there was little exposure.
There was no liberty in that country, so social contact was nonexistent.
Still, when you go into a village or you're patrolling an area, you do need to know the various things that upset a race of people or a certain culture.
For instance, I remember you weren't supposed to pat Vietnamese on the head like you do American children, like you're a good boy or you're a good girl.
That's offensive to them.
If they want to walk in front of you, they will put their hands down like this and kind of bow their head to pass in front of you.
That doesn't mean that they're showing signs of inferiority.
That's just their way of saying, excuse me, to pass it in front of them.
They would not actually say excuse me to an American that looks like they're being subservient to us.
So it's good to know those traits, characteristics, because it keeps you from becoming the ugly American, creating the wrong impression.
On this topic, how about the enlisted men?
When they would go on patrols or go through towns, did they have a problem with, say, respecting the culture?
Particularly, I know the Vietnamese have a habit of holding hands.
Did that cause problems?
I don't think it did.
After you've been there any length of time, you realize that was just their way of doing things.
The Vietnamese are not the only society that hold hands.
It's quite prevalent throughout the Orient.
If you spend any time in the Far East as I had, you knew that that was just one of their customs and practices.
And after you've observed it for a while, it didn't bother you.

I'm sure it bothered the on the list of Marines initially but again all of them went through that three weeks training at Camp Finland and they were told that these type of things happen and it doesn't mean the same thing to them that it does to us.
In going into their villages
found that most of the people were very leery of Americans.
Of course, they were living
to the Americans in daytime, and then the Viet Cong would come out at night.
So they didn't want to appear overly friendly to us.
And they would stay back in their houses or out in their fields and stay away from us.
And it wasn't an atmosphere where, oh, here comes the American, and we'd all flock around him and hope to get chewing gum and candy and that type of thing.
They were very aloof or distant.
They didn't want to have too much contact.
Then at nighttime, the local populace would hole up in their houses or in their village.
There was no contact with the Americans at all at that time.

So really, when a Marine, an infantry Marine, saw a Vietnamese that was on a, he was working, he was out patrolling, passing through a village or around the village, he had very little, well, had no social contact.
He might have to gather people up and search them and move them along from one area to another.
Again, it wasn't social contact.
You were out there doing a job, and you didn't have a chance to see all these type of actions or symbols that the local culture used to be upset.
Now, if you were stationed full-time into May, you'd have greater access to the local populace, or if you were in Saigon,
I'm sure this situation will be completely different.
It could even take classes while you're over there on what the culture is for you to understand that.
All right, sir.
The next question is concerning military leadership and problems such as drugs, careerism, fragging.
Did you have any observations concerning the quality of leadership over there?
Well, I had...
I guess I had observations on the quality of leadership, as well as limited observations on the other subjects that you just mentioned.
I found the leadership to be good.
Of course, as I said, I was a senior captain by those standards.
was more experienced than the other captains.
I have to also point out that the way we operated as an infantry company commander, I had little contact with the other company commanders.
I did by radio, but seldom visually.
We went out as a company and we would operate independently under the guidance of the battalion.
They would direct us by the radio transmission.

but seldom were two companies adjacent to each other in the classic sense of companies online, where daily you would coordinate with the company on your right and the company on your left, and the company in the reserve behind you.
We didn't have that type of environment.
So the only time I got to see the other company commander would be a brief session when we were getting ready to jump off on a battalion-level operation.
And we were all in for a briefing and coordination before we jumped off.
And so I had Lindy in contact with them then.
After the operation, we all flushed and went back to the respective zones.
And never had a chance to see around and just shoot them back.
So the people that I had more experience with were obviously the commanders above me.
I had three battalion commanders, three different battalion commanders while I was a company commander.
And the operations officer I saw all the time had two different operations officers.
And then, of course, the officers who worked for me.
The three battalion commanders that I had were all superb.
One of them, well, one of them, two of them were superb.
One was good, but the other two were just superb.
Both of the operations officers were truly outstanding and did a great job of directing the operations of the battalion.

Concerning the officers and staff non-commissioned officers that worked for me, at that time we were so short of infantry officers that we had to take officers, non-infantry officers, and make them or assign them to the infantry companies for 90 days.
I only, in a six-month period, as I recall, I only had three lieutenants
that had an infantry background.

I had an engineer, tank officer, several different types, and they were there during their initial 90 days of combat duty with the infantry before they would go on to a tank organization or an engineer organization.
So I would say at least 50% of the lieutenants who worked for me were not infantry.
They were in for a great shock when they got there.

They knew that the reason they were there was because infantry officers didn't survive very long, and probably part of the motivation for them being, let's say, an engineering officer as opposed to an infantry officer was he didn't like the infantry type of work.
It just wasn't his cup of tea.
When he got out there and found that he was assigned to an infantry organization, he was probably in shock.
In fairness to those folks, though, I had an engineer officer that was very quiet, but he did a superb job.
He wasn't showy like some infantry officers are.
I was not impressed with him initially, but he got the job done.
His unit was always well prepared and well taken care of.
I had an infantry officer that I had to relieve.
I couldn't trust him.
But I think you'll find that in any situation.
But if I had to stereotype a group of people, I would say that they were all very good.
You'll have your exceptions any time.
People that just aren't fit for that type of duty.
I had one staff non-commissioned officer who was accused of being a coward under fire.
I'm not sure.
I wasn't there on the scene when it occurred, so I don't know if that is, in fact, the truth.
He was a staff mountain commission officer who'd been in the Marine Corps 17 years.
There was a great effort to court-martial him, and I refused to do so.
He had to be the sergeant for the lieutenant, but I didn't trust him.
When I did, I finally got him reassigned to special services.
There was no point, in my view, of taking a man who had spent 17 dedicated years in the Marine Corps and court-martialing him on a thin thread of evidence, as I saw him, and ruining his life.
And I think it would have ruined his life.
He was, because of the actions that were going on, he was very distraught.
I didn't think it was necessary.
All right, sir, did you have any problem with drugs, or did you see any drugs use at all?
I encountered use of drugs one time.
That was back when our company was in a rear area, and we were able to stand down for one night in one of the tents over in the mess area.
This was over in a battalion mess area, not one of mine.
There was a group of people, and I probably had a few people in there, that were smoking marijuana.
That's the only situation, the only occasion that I know of.
When we were out in the field, it simply didn't happen in my company.
We had a policy of anyone who was caught on drugs was immediate non-judicial punishment or court-martial and reduction in rank.

but out in the out in the field or the bushes we call it your life depended on each other and there was a great social stigma for everyone to be alert and prepared and i think the people who used them knew that they were impaired wherever they were spoken to so they didn't do it
Was there an occasional time?
There could have been.
But the thing is, marijuana has a strong, distinctive odor.
You're always checking your positions at nighttime, not only to come to commander, but to commanders and to sergeants.
And you would notice something on the water.
We were out there in the middle of nowhere, where we had to rely on each person.
To my knowledge, it just never happened.
Now, I did hear stories about back in Saigon and back in Da Nang and back in Da Nang, where smoking went on every night, as well as fragging of people, officers and staff, noncommissioned officers.
I've heard of Marine officers being fragged.
I never knew of anyone who was, nor did I, nor was I aware of a specific incident.
Again, I was out in the field for six months and never saw one tree or a dog hawk at all, except the one night I spent going and about the three nights I spent coming back.
I was just unaware of anything at that time.
All right, sir.
Did you see any careerism go on?
Any officers that perhaps were trying to get their ticket punched so they could move up and
Quite the contrary.
And I was really surprised just to have seen that question on the topic sheet that you submitted to me earlier.
I was trying to, I was wondering where the question came from and what was the basis of the question.
I would guess back in Saigon, maybe depending on the higher level staffs,
You might run into queries.
I said, to the contrary, I run into just the opposite.
When my first battalion commander's tour was nearing completion, I asked him one day who was going to be his relief, and he said he didn't know.
He said, there are three infantry battalions, or CO's positions of three infantry battalions, that are coming open within a week or two of each other.
It's time he was leaving.
He said there were 11 lieutenant colonels back at the division headquarters who were eligible to go out and take over the battalion.
At that time, the commanding general's policy was you just didn't take a person from the United States, a lieutenant colonel from the United States, and assign him to a battalion.
You put him on the division staff for four to six months so he could get
the lay of the land, if you will, understand the rules of engagement, the nature of the war, so that he didn't go in unaware of how the war should be fought.
What we found, and what Lieutenant Curcio told me, was that of the 11 lieutenant colonels who were in that situation, one wanted a battalion.
and one other would take the battalion if offered.
This was quite a shock to me as a young officer.
I thought all people aspired for command, particularly in combat.
What it meant was that life was dangerous out there and it was hard, and commanders could get relieved because things didn't go well or go right.
If you were a staff officer in the rear,
get your ticket punched, to use that phrase, get your combat time in, get a good finish report, and go over and come back with your career.
And you didn't get hurt, because as a staff officer it's more difficult to mess up than the SS men do.
If you want to call that careerism, yes, it is.
Kind of a protective careerism.
When I saw the note careerism, I took that in the context of here are officers
They want to get an infantry organization or a command and go out and be daring and take chances and do reckless things in the name of getting hit.
And I certainly didn't see that at all.
It didn't happen with any of the three commanders that I had or any of the company commanders that I associated with or any of the junior officers.
It just didn't happen.
All right, sir.
Concerning your operations that you were on, what...
Were there any failures?
Depends how you classify failures.
If you say you were not successful, you had a failure, you probably could say so, but for instance,
A fire base had been closed, and we went back in to open a fire base and launch new operations against the North Vietnamese.
We bombarded that fire base for about six hours before my company, as the lead company, flew into it.
When we got there, what enemy forces had been there were gone.
It was obvious that we were coming.
We bombarded the area, and we flew in right on the last
shell, so to speak.
Did we find, fix, and destroy any enemy at that point?
No, we didn't.
Was that a successful operation?
Well, at the time, I didn't feel like it was because I hadn't killed any more of the enemy forces.
On the other hand, that was a piece of real estate that we now owned and controlled.
We controlled all the movement in that area, so it was a successful operation.
And that was more typical than atypical, that you would do many combat operations.
Some you would engage the enemy and some you would not.
Where we engaged the enemy, we were always successful.
But we were on one operation with the Vietnamese that we could have been successful.
But we were not.
We were on a large carton operation.
That's where we'd fly in a bunch of units and march in a bunch of units, forming huge rectangle people.
As I recall, the piece of real estate where we fought the North Vietnamese were was about 4 kilometers by 10 kilometers.
We put a carton around this area.
Unfortunately, the Vietnamese soldiers moved in at a different rate of movement than we did, with stuff gaping holes in the carton.
And then over the weekend that we were there, they just sat down, basically shut down.
It didn't work.
It was left gaping holes.
Our game plan was to close down the court and make it smaller and just put a squeeze on the enemy forces that we called in, that intelligence that we had in it.
When we did that, we didn't come under it.
I never saw anyone fleeing, so I don't know if that was...
successful operation or an unsuccessful operation.
It was not successfully executed, from my point of view, because the Vietnamese left gaping holes in the mines.
So had there been North Vietnamese in there, they could have gotten out.
I saw other companies that had
Firefights where they had to leave their people out there for a while, half a day to a day, with their casualties before they could go get them.
As I indicated, most firefights or skirmishes are brief and intense, and if you're caught unprepared, you're going to take some casualties.
Depending on the size of the action, you could take any number from 1 to 10 to 50.
But because you were fighting on another man's turf, he could land into the countryside and he took his casualties with him.
You never knew how many, in most cases, you didn't know how many casualties he suffered.
The engagements were at night.
They were on the outside of you.
Of course, you collected your casualties.
They'd pull theirs off and they were gone.
You come to expect that.
There are occasions when you completely overwhelm them, and you've got their casualties right there.
And so you know that you've got some.
You never know.
All right, sir.
Do you have any more comments on the success of your operations?
Well, I would have to say we were successful.
We didn't take too many casualties.
We moved a great number of people, great distances.
We controlled a lot of land, countryside.
I felt that we could move about fairly freely now.
By that I don't mean loosely, without proper security.
But I was not fearful of moving anywhere.
By using proper tactics and having proper security, you go moving from point A to point B, from one mountain to another mountain, through a valley up to the militarized zone.
Now, there are times when it gets scary.
But I was confident enough that we could move about day and night.
So from that point of view, it had to be successful.
I think we controlled the countryside.
All right, sir.
The next portion of the interview will deal with your views.
All right, sir.
All right, sir.
If you could comment on your views of the Arvin.
Well, again, I had very little contact with him.
Of course, I was over there twice.
What many Americans don't realize, or didn't realize,
is that the Vietnamese had been in a war for many years before the Americans got there.
It became a day of life for them, or an existing routine.
The war had probably been going on 10 years before we got there.
In their view, it could go on another 10 years or another 20 years.
And so their outlook on fighting a war was completely different.
The Americans' outlook on the war is to get in there, prosecute the war to the fullest, and then get out as quickly as you can.
So we went in there eager, wanted to engage the enemy, defeat him, wash our hands of the whole mess, and then get out of the country.

and when you see someone who doesn't whose actions don't indicate they believe the same thing you tend to look at them as if they're not good soldiers they're not good military people are they just not good people in general and that's certainly not the case with the vietnamese i think the vietnamese were very very industrious people that surely been borne out by those
the boat people, the refugees who have come to this country.
They're dedicated people.
They believe in their family.
First of all, the Vietnamese believe in their family more than anything else.
I don't think Americans can say that.
We probably have, most Americans have stronger ties to their country than they do their family.
Vietnam is family first, country second.
I'm not sure that's the case in this case.
But they moved at a different pace than we did.
They were war-weary.
They'd been fighting for 10 years.
We came over there for 12 months and got out.
We, being individuals, came over there for 12 months and got out.
I'm sure it would be hard to get a bunch of the enemy's hyped up.
Okay, we're going to go out and build a crushing blow to the mountain.
After ten years, you know, so many types of going out and did a crushing blow.
What was one more?
It just wasn't going to happen.
Then we came in there with all of our muscle and might and ready to hold the war for them.
I can't really blame, particularly in hindsight, those people for sitting back and saying, we're going to have this big showy bully.
I'm not calling us bullies, but this big showy guy who's coming in and going to show us how to fight a war.
OK, well, we'll just sit back and let him do it.
We'll see what situation the Vietnamese is in now.
I think they should have sat back and let us do it, but we sure did.
take over the country and turn it back over to them in such a shape that they wouldn't be able to belong.
And the South Vietnamese people are the same people as the North Vietnamese.
I have the greatest admiration for the North Vietnamese.
I'm sure with proper leadership
of the South Vietnamese, their organizations were just as good, just as fierce.
There were some units there in the Da Nang area, I don't recall the names, but they had a tremendous economy.
And I think the Ontario organization, it's a function of leadership.
It's a good organization.
I think the Vietnamese were properly led and motivated.
All right, sir.
Do you have any, in your experiences with the ARVN, any command conflicts?
No.
I did not, because mainly I was at a level where we did not have to coordinate the supporting fires.
That went on at a level below me.
I am aware of conflicts.
For instance, you have
fire support zones.
If something was going on near you that was in another zone, then you couldn't fire there without it being cleared by his adjacent zone commander.
And we do that in actual combat operations, but we didn't have the dual clearance of the U.S. military commander and then the Vietnamese zone commander.
But I've heard that was a problem that their parents were not timely, but I never experienced it.
All right, sir.
I need to change the tape now.
